0.description: Chicha modeled itself on Colombian Cumbia music, replaced the accordion with surf guitars, incorporated the psychedelic sounds of organs, synths, guajira, and the pentatonic scales of Andean melodies. This is the first ever Chicha compilation released outside of Peru.

1.description: Raised on Colombia’s Caribbean coast and united by its capital, Ghetto Kumbé combines their musical heritage to invoke the spirit of digital rumba globally. The secret to their electronic ritual lies in their powerful percussion base fusing, Carribean house & West African Rhythms.

2.description: Celebrating early 70s Peruvian cumbia and funk with Andean melodies, Cuban son fused with surf guitars, Farfisa organs and Moog synths. They push their music beyond mere pastiche and into experimental and interesting re-interpretations of chicha and pop classics.

3.description: We always had a few shots before performing. Our local cachaça had loosened the bodies and minds of everyone, people would pair off and twirl to the sound of forró music, smiling and sliding their feet off the floor - a reflex picked up from dancing in rural villages to avoid kicking up the dust.

4.description: Recorded in an improvised studio set up by Maga Bo in Mãe Biu, in the terreiro of Xambá in Olinda. The intention was to bring Grupo Bongar into a familiar atmosphere where Guitinho could compose music and lyrics on the spot, inspired by the history of the Xambá community.

5.description: The siku is a wind instrument of Andean origin, symbolic in ancestral rituals, made up of two complementary parts, the arca and the ira. It is a symbol of duality, essetnital to the indigenous view of involvement and complementarity, unlike binary thinking typical of the west.

6.description: Cenotes marries influences of Dub & IDM with the rhythms and melodies of Latin American & Andean folk. Fused with sounds of waterfalls, birdsongs and crackling leaves, resulting in a deep melodic journey that entrances as much through headphones as it does on the dancefloor.

7.description: Recorded in their home studio in Lima, their album “Karimba” (hot iron used to mark the cattle and slaves) takes Novalima's music to new levels, fusing new sounds and traditional rhythms like the Panalivio, Zamacueca, Ingá and Tondero, while maintaining their distinctive afro and dub sound.

0.description: Palestine is a land rich in history, arts, and culture. It is also the birthplace of unique electronic music and hip-hop artists. Artists who have forged a music scene founded on the desire to unite people and break free from oppression. May justice forever prevail over the evils of injustice.

1.description: My flat was destroyed in 2020’s Beirut explosion. The suburbs were a bittersweet retreat from the city drama, at least for a few months. Jad Atoui would visit sometimes and we would record music, jamming new ideas on modular synths. Here’s three selected edits. - Jawad Nawfal

2.description: Best friends who consistently managed to package the socio-political state into art. Rebels of their time with a deep insight into the streets of Lebanon, this was sadly their last album, as Joseph Sakr would pass away shortly after its release. A memento of their unified genius and creativity.

3.description: This is the result of the encounter of Shady Rabab (creator of instruments from garbage, music) and Rafik Rezine (aka Daynassour). This album relies solely on musical instruments made from garbage, and on electronic sounds created from the sounds of these instruments.

4.description: I wanted to highlight this artist duo. "Build Your Castles" is my favorite track by them. The lyrics reflect upon themes of opression and imprisonment on a socio-politcal level, abstracted through poetry. Their latest album ">1 Greater Than One" is a mesemerizing experience.

5.description: Released in December 2009 at a steel factory in Bourj Hammoud, an unprecedented number of attendees crowded the factory yard. The gig turned out to be Beirut's biggest non-mainstream event in recent years and has been a big hit among indie and rock fans in Lebanon.

6.description: Let him pass. That’s the document the stateless carry. It’s all that those from the occupied Golan Heights possess. Since 1967 the area has been part of Israel, but the inhabitants aren’t Israelis. They don’t have any citizenship. They don’t have passports. Just a Laissez Passer.

7.description: El Waili started his music career experimenting with sounds, melodies, and textures in electronic music. His “El Waili” project started in 2020 with a track named ‘2010’ and ‘El Abd Wa El Waili’, to place his mark in the electro-chaabi/EDM music scene. A true experimentalist.

0.description: The Tunisian vocalist and oud player Dhafer Youssef steeps his compositions in the modes and rhythms of the Middle East. Melodies gently curl the contours of Arabic scales, as winds dance over Turkish low-register drones, all to intricate Indian rhythmic structures.

1.description: Sorie Kondi is a blind musician with like no person I have met before,” explains Boima. “My work with him began with a YouTube link. I spotted the video for his track ‘Without Money No Family’ and was struck by his beautiful vocals and socially-conscious lyrics, and a will to thrive like no other.

2.description: Lenna Bahule, recognized for her powerful voice and innovative fusion of traditional Mozambican and Afro sounds, with organic materials and sung in several African languages, offers a deep and immersive experience that resonates with the body, mind and soul.

3.description: Tinariwen are Tuaregs, children of a nomadic Berber tribe who have roamed the Saharan desert for thousands of years. Over recent centuries, colonialism has seen the Tuareg’s ancestral territory partitioned into distinct countries - Mali, Algeria, Libya, Niger. Their music has shed light on their strife.

4.description: ONIPA means ‘human’ in Akan, the ancient language of the Ashanti people of Ghana. It’s a message of connection through collaboration: from Ghana to London, our ancestors to our children, Onipa brings energy, groove, electronics, afrofuturism, dance and fire! combining afro, electronics and fierce energy.

5.description: The revered name Ambuya? ("Grandmother") with a question mark - becomes Ambuya! with an exclamation mark. The "Queen of Mbira" Stella Chiweshe has earned this not only with her music but also with her attitude and self-assertion. Her voice, fierce and mesmerizing, charms you through its melodies.

6.description: Emmanuel’s message of peace has carried through all of his work, whether it be his latest book "My Life is Art", his memoir "Warchild", his widely-shared Ted Talk, co-starring with Reese Witherspoon in the motion picture "The Good Lie", and even reconciling with healthy eating by launching the instant powder super food "Jal Gua".

7.description: Nakibembe Xylophone Group are one of the last remaining groups that perform with the embaire. Listening to the album is like hearing the past, present and future aligned; dance music is not bound to its contemporary apparatus, and conversation rather than colonization can stretch beyond borders.

0.description: The tradition of Indian percussion was revolutionized in the late 20th century by the prolific, award-winning, tabla maestro Zakir Hussain. The son of Ustad Allah Rakha, Hussain inherited his father's thirst for bringing the music of India to the international stage. His hundreds of recording credits.

1.description: The production is based on regional folk music traditions, recorded and brought back to the studio to create a composition that mixes and arranges the original recordings, and embarks on a visual and musical journey crossing borders, while preserving the music of the people.

2.description: Business Class Refugees is a global, collaborative project by music producer Kartick (Patrick Sebag) and sound designer Gotam (Yotam Agam), who mix local music from around the world with electronica. This album is where Kartick & Gotam's journey began: India. The project has no end.
